items.title: Minneapolis mayor accuses federal authorities of ‘hiding facts’ in ICE killing
items.standfirst: Jacob Frey criticizes Trump administration’s response to shooting death of Renee Nicole GoodOfficials in Minneapolis on Friday accused federal authorities of “hiding the facts” over the killing of a US citizen by an officer with the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agency, and demanded the inclusion of state investigators in the FBI inquiry.Jacob Frey, the Minnesota city’s Democratic mayor, criticized the Trump administration’s response to the shooting, speaking at a press conference two days after the death of Renee Nicole Good in her car in a confrontation with federal officers amid protests and community scrutiny during an immigration crackdown. Continue reading...
items.content: Jacob Frey criticizes Trump administration’s response to shooting death of Renee Nicole GoodOfficials in Minneapolis on Friday accused federal authorities of “hiding the facts” over the killing of a US citizen by an officer with the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agency, and demanded the inclusion of state investigators in the FBI inquiry.Jacob Frey, the Minnesota city’s Democratic mayor, criticized the Trump administration’s response to the shooting, speaking at a press conference two days after the death of Renee Nicole Good in her car in a confrontation with federal officers amid protests and community scrutiny during an immigration crackdown. Continue reading...

items.title: Minneapolis mayor slams Trump officials for Renee Good comments, calls for transparency
items.standfirst: Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey held a press conference on Friday and called for transparency from federal agencies that have taken over the investigation into the Renee Good shooting. Frey also slammed comments from Trump administration officials about the incident. CBS News' Ash-har Quraishi reports.
items.content: Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey held a press conference on Friday and called for transparency from federal agencies that have taken over the investigation into the Renee Good shooting. Frey also slammed comments from Trump administration officials about the incident. CBS News' Ash-har Quraishi reports.

items.title: Iran’s supreme leader sets stage for harsher crackdown as protest movement swells
items.standfirst: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei calls protesters ‘vandals’ and ‘saboteurs’ and blames the US for instigating the unrestIran’s supreme leader has vowed that authorities will “not back down” in the face of a rapidly growing protest movement, setting the stage for an intensified violent crackdown on the second day of a nationwide internet shutdown.Protests have raged in cities and towns across the country in recent days, posing a threat to the authority of the regime, which has been significantly weakened since the last large protest movement in the country in 2022. Another round of demonstrations was called for Friday night. Continue reading...
items.content: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei calls protesters ‘vandals’ and ‘saboteurs’ and blames the US for instigating the unrestIran’s supreme leader has vowed that authorities will “not back down” in the face of a rapidly growing protest movement, setting the stage for an intensified violent crackdown on the second day of a nationwide internet shutdown.Protests have raged in cities and towns across the country in recent days, posing a threat to the authority of the regime, which has been significantly weakened since the last large protest movement in the country in 2022. Another round of demonstrations was called for Friday night. Continue reading...

items.title: Meta Turns to Multi-Gigawatt Nuclear Deals for AI Data Centers
items.standfirst: Meta aims to future-proof its energy needs by turning to nuclear power in multi-gigawatt deals for AI data centers. Bloomberg’s Riley Griffin discusses Meta’s plan with Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Tech." (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: Meta aims to future-proof its energy needs by turning to nuclear power in multi-gigawatt deals for AI data centers. Bloomberg’s Riley Griffin discusses Meta’s plan with Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Tech." (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: AI Build-Out Forces Analysts to Cover Entire Supply Chain
items.standfirst: Meta agreed to a series of electricity deals for AI data centers that will make it the biggest buyer of nuclear power among its hyperscaler peers. Paul Meeks, managing director and head of technology research at Freedom Capital Markets, discusses how energy needs and the AI build-out are changing what tech analysts examine. He joins Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Tech." (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: Meta agreed to a series of electricity deals for AI data centers that will make it the biggest buyer of nuclear power among its hyperscaler peers. Paul Meeks, managing director and head of technology research at Freedom Capital Markets, discusses how energy needs and the AI build-out are changing what tech analysts examine. He joins Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Tech." (Source: Bloomberg)

items.content: Oklo Inc. and Vistra Corp. shares rallied, leading peers higher, after Meta Platforms Inc. agreed to a purchase nuclear power from the companies to run artificial-intelligence data centers.

items.title: Meta Signs Multi-Gigawatt Nuclear Deals to Power AI Data Centers

items.content: Meta Platforms Inc. agreed to a series of electricity deals to power data centers that could end up totaling more than 6 gigawatts, enough to power a city of about 5 million homes. Will Wade reports on Bloomberg Television. (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: EU states back controversial Mercosur deal with Latin American countries
items.standfirst: Agreement after 25 years of negotiations prompts farmers to block roads in Paris, Brussels and WarsawEuropean Union member states have backed the biggest ever free trade agreement with a group of Latin American countries, ending 25 years of negotiations but stoking further tensions with farmers and environmentalists around the bloc.The contentious Mercosur deal with Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay prompted immediate protests in Poland, France, Greece and Belgium, with farmers blocking key roads in Paris, Brussels and Warsaw. Continue reading...
items.content: Agreement after 25 years of negotiations prompts farmers to block roads in Paris, Brussels and WarsawEuropean Union member states have backed the biggest ever free trade agreement with a group of Latin American countries, ending 25 years of negotiations but stoking further tensions with farmers and environmentalists around the bloc.The contentious Mercosur deal with Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay prompted immediate protests in Poland, France, Greece and Belgium, with farmers blocking key roads in Paris, Brussels and Warsaw. items.title: EU states back record South America trade deal after 25 years
items.standfirst: EU states gave a provisional go-ahead on Friday for the bloc to sign its largest ever free trade accord with South American group Mercosur, more than 25 years since talks began and after months of wrangling to secure enough backers.
items.content: EU states gave a provisional go-ahead on Friday for the bloc to sign its largest ever free trade accord with South American group Mercosur, more than 25 years since talks began and after months of wrangling to secure enough backers.

items.title: Glencore and Rio Tinto are at it again – and it seems the markets smell action
items.standfirst: Many of the old challenges remain but there are a number of reasons why this time a deal of some kind could be possibleMining firms Rio Tinto and Glencore restart $260bn merger talksHere we go again. A combination of Rio Tinto and Glencore has been talked about for years and the duo held aborted negotiations at the end of 2024. With the global mining industry in deal-making mode – frenzies come along every 15 years or so – the idea of RioGlen or GlenTinto was due another whirl. On Friday, the two FTSE 100 companies said they were in “preliminary discussions” about a “possible combination of some or all of their businesses”. A full-blown tie-up would be worth about $260bn (£120bn), including debt.Many of the old challenges to a deal haven’t gone away. Glencore’s roots lie in trading commodities; Rio is a traditional pure miner, so the fit is culturally imperfect. Does Rio, which got out of coal as long ago as 2018 under investor pressure, really want to go back in by adding Glencore’s significant assets in that area? Reports suggested it is prepared to do so. But, if not, should coal be hived off beforehand? Should Glencore’s trading operation go with it? Continue reading...
items.content: Many of the old challenges remain but there are a number of reasons why this time a deal of some kind could be possibleMining firms Rio Tinto and Glencore restart $260bn merger talksHere we go again. A combination of Rio Tinto and Glencore has been talked about for years and the duo held aborted negotiations at the end of 2024. With the global mining industry in deal-making mode – frenzies come along every 15 years or so – the idea of RioGlen or GlenTinto was due another whirl. On Friday, the two FTSE 100 companies said they were in “preliminary discussions” about a “possible combination of some or all of their businesses”. A full-blown tie-up would be worth about $260bn (£120bn), including debt.Many of the old challenges to a deal haven’t gone away. Glencore’s roots lie in trading commodities; Rio is a traditional pure miner, so the fit is culturally imperfect. Does Rio, which got out of coal as long ago as 2018 under investor pressure, really want to go back in by adding Glencore’s significant assets in that area? Reports suggested it is prepared to do so. But, if not, should coal be hived off beforehand? Should Glencore’s trading operation go with it? Continue reading...

items.title: Mining firms Rio Tinto and Glencore restart $260bn merger talks
items.standfirst: Deal would create world’s largest mining company and come almost a year after previous discussions failedNils Pratley: Glencore and Rio Tinto are at it again – and the markets smell actionRio Tinto and Glencore have restarted talks over a merger that would create the world’s largest mining company.The talks come almost a year after previous discussions between the two mining companies collapsed. If a deal is agreed, it would create a global mining business with an enterprise value of more than $260bn (£193bn). Continue reading...
items.content: Deal would create world’s largest mining company and come almost a year after previous discussions failedNils Pratley: Glencore and Rio Tinto are at it again – and the markets smell actionRio Tinto and Glencore have restarted talks over a merger that would create the world’s largest mining company.The talks come almost a year after previous discussions between the two mining companies collapsed. If a deal is agreed, it would create a global mining business with an enterprise value of more than $260bn (£193bn). Continue reading...
